Introdudon
The ability to observe the function of a single
ion channel has significantly advanced the
field of neurophysiology in the past decade.
Fast reversible transitions between closed and
open channel states are stochastic by nature
and governed by membrane potential, chan-
nel current, and various ligands [27].
The behavior of a single channel contra-
dicts certain aspects of an earlier channel
model [I] used to explain the kinetics of
averaged current through excitable mem-
branes; therefore, the model needs to be modi-
fied to take into account activating and
inactivating gates, the nature and functioning
of electric field sensors and gating particles,
and mechanisms of diverse channel modu-
lators. The similarity in behavior of single
channels of different types (Na+, Ca2+, and
K+) may point to common principles under-
lying channel function.
Investigators are attempting to establish
regularities in the physical and chemical pro-
perties of channel-forming structures and of
compounds affecting channel function in
order to clarify the mechanisms of action of
the channels and their modulators. The chan-
nels of excitable membranes are formed by
proteins, for which the primary structures of
